answers.q: what is sodium thiosulfate used for
answers.a: As a food additive (E539), it functions as an antioxidant and sequestrant, binding trace metals and helping prevent oxidation; it’s also used to neutralize residual chlorine in processing water.

answers.q: how much sodium thiosulfate to neutralize chlorine
answers.a: About 7 parts of sodium thiosulfate pentahydrate (Na2S2O3·5H2O) are needed per 1 part of chlorine (as Cl2) by weight—for example, ~7 mg/L thiosulfate per 1 mg/L free chlorine; in practice, a small excess is often used.

answers.q: is gold sodium thiosulfate in makeup
answers.a: Gold sodium thiosulfate is a different compound from food additive E539 and isn’t typically used in cosmetics; check the ingredient list if you’re concerned about gold-containing ingredients.

answers.q: how many elements are in sodium thiosulfate
answers.a: Anhydrous sodium thiosulfate (Na2S2O3) contains 3 elements (Na, S, O); the common pentahydrate (Na2S2O3·5H2O) includes 4 (adds H from the water of crystallization).
In foods it acts as an antioxidant and sequestrant, helping prevent oxidation and off-colors by binding metals, and it can dechlorinate processing water.
